question: What effect does wind drag have on the direction of ocean surface currents?

content.source_1: Wind stress transfers momentum to the ocean surface; on a rotating Earth this produces an Ekman response in which the directly wind-driven surface current is deflected by the Coriolis effectâ€”right of the wind in the Northern Hemisphere and left in the Southern.
content.source_2: Classical Ekman theory predicts the surface current flows at about 45 degrees to the wind and weakens and rotates with depth (the Ekman spiral); the depth-integrated Ekman transport is 90 degrees to the wind.
content.source_3: The pattern of surface circulation broadly follows the prevailing wind belts: trade winds drive westward equatorial surface currents, and midlatitude westerlies drive eastward currents, so surface currents tend to follow wind direction.
content.source_4: A practical oceanographic rule of thumb is that wind-driven surface drift is roughly 2 percent of the wind speed and generally aligned with the wind direction at the surface.
content.source_5: The Coriolis effect vanishes at the equator, so directly wind-driven surface motion there is not laterally deflected by rotation and tends to align with the wind.
content.source_6: Observations with current meters and surface drifters show that, away from the equator, directly wind-forced currents are systematically offset to the right of the wind in the Northern Hemisphere and to the left in the Southern, consistent with Ekman deflection.

answer: deflection of water toward the direction of airflow
